content: The "Individual Retirement Account Equity and Enhancement Act of 1994" allows homemakers to be eligible for a full IRA deduction. The "Individual Retirement Account Equity and Enhancement Act of 1994" allows homemakers to be eligible for a full IRA deduction. Spousal IRA rules are amended to base contributions on the combined compensation of both spouses. The "Individual Retirement Account Equity and Enhancement Act of 1994" allows homemakers to be eligible for a full IRA deduction based on combined spousal compensation for joint filers. The "Individual Retirement Account Equity and Enhancement Act of 1994" allows homemakers to be eligible for a full IRA deduction based on combined spousal compensation for joint filers. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1994, including adjustments to certain definitions and rules. Distributions from certain plans can be used penalty-free to buy first homes, pay for higher education or long-term care, or by the long-term unemployed. Distributions from certain plans can be used penalty-free for first home purchases, educational expenses, or long-term care. Qualified first-time homebuyer distributions are defined as payments received by an individual for purchasing a first home, without penalty. Qualified first-time homebuyer distributions refer to payments or distributions received by an individual to pay for qualified acquisition costs related to a first home within 60 days. Qualified first-time homebuyer distributions are payments received by an individual for acquiring, constructing, or reconstructing a residence, including settlement and closing costs. The term 'first-time homebuyer' refers to an individual, their spouse, child, or grandchild. The term 'first-time homebuyer' means an individual who had no ownership interest in a principal residence for 3 years before acquiring a new residence, and certain sections did not suspend this. The term 'principal residence' has the same meaning as in section 1034, and the term 'date of acquisition' is defined. The distribution is made according to subparagraph (A)(ii), defining 'principal residence' and 'date of acquisition' as in section 1034. A special rule applies in case of a delay in acquisition. "If a distribution from an individual retirement plan fails to meet the requirements of subparagraph (A) due to a delay in acquiring or constructing a principal residence, the amount may be contributed to another individual retirement plan within 120 days." "For qualified higher education expenses, the term includes tuition, fees, books, supplies, and equipment necessary for enrollment or attendance." The term 'qualified higher education expenses' includes tuition, fees, books, supplies, and equipment required for enrollment at an eligible educational institution for the taxpayer, spouse, child, or grandchild. The curr_chunk discusses the definition of qualified long-term care expenses for tax purposes, including payments for services and insurance. It also mentions the coordination of qualified higher education expenses with savings bond provisions. The curr_chunk defines qualified long-term care expenses as payments for necessary diagnostic, preventive, therapeutic, rehabilitative, and maintenance services for functionally impaired individuals. The curr_chunk specifies that personal care services must be provided to functionally impaired individuals as part of a continuing plan of care prescribed by a licensed health care practitioner. The text chunk discusses the definition of a functionally impaired individual as someone certified by a licensed health care practitioner as unable to perform tasks without substantial assistance. The text chunk defines a functionally impaired individual as someone certified by a licensed health care practitioner as unable to perform at least 3 activities of daily living without substantial assistance. The text chunk specifies that for home health care services provided to individuals residing at home, the requirement of being unable to perform 3 activities of daily living is reduced to 2. Nursing homes or similar facilities are not considered as homes. The text specifies that nursing homes or similar facilities are not considered homes for the purpose of defining activities of daily living, which include eating, transferring, toileting, dressing, and bathing. A licensed health care practitioner is defined as a physician or registered professional nurse. A licensed health care practitioner, as defined in the text, includes a physician, registered professional nurse, qualified community care case manager, or any individual meeting requirements set by the Secretary after consultation with the Secretary of Health and Human Services. A qualified community care case manager is an individual or entity with experience in providing case management services, preparing care plans, and assessing individuals. A qualified community care case manager must have experience in providing case management services, preparing care plans, and assessing individuals for functional and cognitive impairment. They cannot be a relative of the individual receiving services and must meet requirements set by the Secretary. Penalty-Free Distributions for Certain Unemployed Individuals: A distribution from an individual retirement plan to an individual after separation from employment, if the individual meets specified criteria. Penalty-Free Distributions for Certain Unemployed Individuals: Amendments allow distributions from an individual retirement plan to an individual after separation from employment if specific conditions are met. Amendments allow penalty-free distributions from an individual retirement plan to an individual after separation from employment under certain conditions, including distributions for qualified first-time homebuyer expenses or qualified higher education expenses. Amendments to section 403(b)(11) allow penalty-free distributions for qualified first-time homebuyer expenses, qualified higher education expenses, and qualified long-term care expenses. Amendments to section 403(b)(11) allow penalty-free distributions for qualified first-time homebuyer expenses, qualified higher education expenses, and qualified long-term care expenses, effective for payments and distributions after the enactment of this Act.
